The best multiplayer shooter I've ever played. There are hundreds of things to learn. The game is divided into different game modes (like Warfare, Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Duel, Capture The Flag, Vehicle Capture The Flag, ...), and the community is constantly creating new mutators and new maps, so it never gets boring.

It doesn't matter how tired you are before the game: As soon you're in the game you feel like on adrenaline with eyes wide open and an alert mind. You will hardly experience a boring moment. So if you are looking for a comfy boring game to call it a day and make yourself ready for sleep --- then you are completely wrong with UT3. In the first few weeks UT3 felt kind of ridiculous fast.

However, after a while my brain adapted and I got used it. Since then, whenever I try to play another shooter  the new shooter feels slow like sneaking and without dodge and wall dodge movement like beeing an immobile target.

In other words: It takes you a while to get accustomed with UT3. But once you mastered it you are like edicted and it's hard to go back playing other shooters.

reviewText:
After putting over 100 hours on UT3, I still like UT2K4 more, but I do feel it has one thing going for it. That's the Vehicle Capture-The-Flag gamemode.

It is the perfect combination of teamwork and individual skill. There needs to be someone who can snatch the enemies flag and move it effectively while being gimped (Flag carriers cannot use vehicles). The rest of the team needs to simultaneously support the carrier as well as protect their own flag.

All of this is made more complex by a diverse array of vehicles and this is further complicated by the fact that one team may not have the same vehicles available to them as the opposition. And somehow the game maintains balance! It is an incredible feat of game and map design.

This game has other merits worth mentioning. It's still gorgeous after all this time. Soundtrack lives up to the brand. The Godlike AI is still intelligent as hell (aggravatingly so on vanillla CTF).

Definitely worth your money and the time your minced bits will layer the walls like a grisly fresco.

reviewText: Unreal Tournament 3 is another great UT game. Graphics and sounds are amazing as always, gameplay is quick and engaging, there are a lot of interesting and varied weapons, vehicles and maps. However, when compared to the older games in the series it doesn't seem to be the best. When it comes to Warfare/Onslaught (same mode, differently called in UT3 and UT2004), then UT2004 seems to be the best as the gameplay is better thought-through and generally maps seem to be better too. It also feels like the developers went too far with vehicles in this mode in UT3, and in consequence there is just too many kinds of them where some don't even seem very useful. When it comes to Deathmatch/Team Deathmatch or Capture the Flag, then the first Unreal Tournament still remains the best up to this day, in my opinion. It has the most solid gameplay in DM/TDM/CtF and no other game in the series ever came close to it.\n\nDo I recommend UT3? Sure, it's a great game in itself, however, even more I would recommend the first UT or UT2004 (depending on what game modes you want to play). Still, even if you own the older games in the series you still might want to get UT3 on a sale just to check it out, at least to play on some different maps than you usually do.

reviewText: UT3 by Epic Games is the fourth game in the Unreal Tournament series and the eigth Unreal game. It runs on their Unreal 3 engine (hence the name) and it looks stunning. The gameplay is tight, the graphics are beautiful and the physics and particle (and gore) effects are amazing. Even though it's five years old the graphics can be tweaked to insane amounts and although it runs at a good framerate on my mid-range hardware if I were to max this baby out it would really push my system to the limits. If you're a fan of Unreal Tournament you'll probably enjoy this game for what it is but it does a few things differently than its predecessors that may annoy you. For one, UT3 focuses heavily on vehicle based combat. Now, I'm a big UT'99 fan and I felt it was possibly the most pure shooter experience I've ever had the joy of playing and it didn't need gimicks like fancy ships, hoverboards (seriously, you get a hoverboard to fly around on on bigger maps), and giant maps to be a great arena shooter. All you needed was running, and gunning. Now, that's not saying that UT3 lacks this, it certainly has smaller maps without hoverboards where you fly around and blast people to bloody bits just like the older games but it does have new mechanics you may like or dislike, such as the ability to play dead" and fall down

On the other hand, if this is your first experience with an Unreal Tournament game, you might not immediately feel like UT3 is your kind of shooter. reviewText:
{This review will be based on the singleplayer mode of this game.}

Unreal Tournament 3. Hmm what to say, what to say... Most of the fans were for strange reasons disappointed of this game. But in my sight (That just for some reason is in love of underated stuffs,) I enjoy this game.

'Tis sad it got a low amount of users playing online, but in there the game is quite intense, unlike with bots. And by the way: Speaking of bots, some of them may be strangely made. Especially in Campaign, which is mostly just made out of low-skilled bots with the constant 'warfare' mode. And this review will be mostly, based on that.

---

Unlike the single players of the previous Unreal Tournament games, there is a special story in it, with (I think) the whole campaign being played with you and your teammates, bots, in missions. There are no actual tournaments and this feeling of arena that was from previous games, but constant war. Without any spoilers, I will just describe the game inside it;

From the start you play on with flags with your small team and the enemy team, that actually know how to use 'translocators' pretty well. But of course, too novice. Sadly the whole continuity of the single player is made out of novice bots. Even your teammates achieve no skill in progress, seriously. Only enemies get to...evolve. But by a little bit. I was disappointed that the parody-race of Skaarj were not as monstrous as they looked.
The gameplay itself with the story goes on solid. Through the missions with flags you then get to complete them in more complex maps, then to the cores with vehicles and prime nodes, and so on for a long time. Sometimes you may get an extra mission, however. It is truly a good feeling when you get back to the deathmatches from these time-consuming warfares.
And later of the game, of course, gets strangely hard. I say strangely because even your epic skills in gaming may not always help your stubborn teammates that cannot even protect the nodes correctly. But thankfully, you got a fuction close to the 'Taunt' and 'Status' section called 'Orders,' since you are a leader and all. It does benefit you a little. Most of the time just do 'Defend' for all the teammates not to get molested by the incoming horde of smarter attacking bots.

But overall...I played this campaign when my internet was out. For some reason I was just, entertained by it. Even with slightly funny way of this game being made, I was digged in a little. Because of my boredom and because of my love to the look of this game, and the whole love to the UT series. Not to look at the negatives of the game, when you imagine it all, more lively of a game, like a movie, it is enjoyable. Though not for the users who seek for an excellent game.

reviewText:
As a fan of slow paced tactical shooters, I have to say this game can appeal to a lot of people. The gameplay is straight forward, and all weapons are easy to use.

The art style matches the gameplay, as a super action sci-fi style movie setting. Any other setting for it is stupid. The characters are joking and colorful... most of them, anyway. Bishop's lines are the best. So if you're that kind of person who pays attention to atmosphere, it doesn't fail here.

When it comes to gameplay, imagine the gunplay of Quake combined with the vehicles of Halo. Nothing much to say here. There are basic Source-inspired movement techniques, such as jumping with weapons and bunny hopping. There are many ways to play, but I categorize them based off their representatives from the Campaign. For example, as I'm used to games where headshots are important, I would be Bishop. Vehicles are of the standard selection: buggies, hover planes, tanks, and a heavier buggy. However, all these vehicles differ from their standard Halo inspirations. For example, the buggy has fold-out blades on the front bumper. Yeah. There are no overpowered weapons or vehicles, but I have to say that the Bio Rifle does a bit too much damage for a gun found right outside of spawn.

The creator tool is a creator tool using the same engine as the game. Not much to say.

TL;DR, It's a good arena game that tops even Half-Life 2 Deathmatch. Gameplay is fluid, art style actually makes sense, so get it if you don't suck at shooters.

EDIT: The Free To Play Unreal Tournament currently outclasses this game in the modes it has, however, it doesn't have vehicles or hoverboards yet. Also no Warfare. So get this if you need to catch up on the series or are extremely impatient.

reviewText:
This game is, without a doubt, amazing! I could rattle on about it, so instead, here's a list of rpos and cons:

Pros
-- Game pace is fast and brilliant
-- The AI (bots) are well programmed but, as usual, teamwork is a lot harder (if not impossible) with bots, so sometimes you have to work around them to get something done. This isn't always a bad thing because it can make the game very interesting.
-- The variety of weapons is good and, in my experience, aren't quite as easy to learn to use well as you might expect. This is not CoD, so becoming proficient with a weapon actually takes practice.
-- The vehicles are fun and well done. The only one I have a problem with is the tank because if you have someone with have a brain operating the turrent, you really do need your whole team to be able to kill it. But this is probably me being too picky.
--The way all the elements of the game fit together forms a game which is truely amazing.


Cons
-- Even though there is a story, playing the maps (at least the first few) doesn't really make it feel like there is. All the objectives I've played so far are all TDM, CTF, CTF with vehicles, etc and it doesn't feel very story-like.
-- It may be the comuter me and my mates have, it might not, but we did run into a few issues when joining each others games on lane. But we'd still be able to join 6 or 7 times out of 10, so it's not enough to be bothered by, but enough to annoy you a little.

Other Comments
-- This game is very reminiscent of Gears of War in the way things look. This is neither a pro nor con, but is cool if you loved and played any of the Gears of War franchise.

Overall, this game is bloody amazing and would highly recommend!
My score : 8/10

reviewText:
Funny thing: I bought this game way back near to the time it came out, as I was super hyped for it. Unreal Tournament has always been my favourite FPS series. Anyway, I got my copy as the regular edition of the game from a retail store. I never bothered registering the key on Steam until years later, as I think I tried it once, and, it didn't work. Then I tried it again, and... it did. Not only that, it gave me the Black Edition. I'm okay with this.

Anyway. The game itself is pretty good. It's like a shinier, prettier UT 2004. I... don't really like it that much. The guns just feel all wrong. It's not a BAD game by anyone's standards. UT3 (which is a very stupid, VERY very stupid title, I mean, it's not the third Unreal game, it's not the third Unreal Tournament game, where did they get the number 3 from... just wtf) is a fantastic game in fact. It's just that I think UT 2004 is a bit better. UT3 doesn't really have many issues I don't think. It just doesn't feel right.

Pick it up on sale, I guess, if you're really devoted to the series. I'm not sure the multiplayer isn't dead.

Also, to address the title situation in more detail... lets see here. Unreal, then Unreal Tournament, then Unreal Tournament 2003, then Unreal II: The Awakening, then Unreal Tournament 2004, then Unreal Tournament 3.

So... where do they get the 3 from? The third Unreal Tournament game was 2004. If it were Unreal 3, that would make it the third Unreal game. But it's not called that. It's called Unreal Tournament 3. What were they thinking? Seriously, I guess the fact this game actually has a campaign of sorts makes it a bit more of an Unreal 3, but at the same time... what?

In Unreal, you're a prisoner who ends up crashed on a planet, you escape the dead vessel, and then you go out into the world to find a way off the planet, and in the process, rack up an insanely huge body count, tear through an alien temple, and destroy the mother of an evil alien race. Among other things. It's awesome, and crazy.

In Unreal 2, you're a space marshal guy who does objective based missions in space. I don't really have much more to say about it. You hang out with your spaceship pals, learn some tragic pasts, get a whole pile of awesome guns, and massacre hundreds of mercs and aliens. Great stuff.

Then... what, you're telling me this is meant to be Unreal 3? Is it? Maybe it is. The campaign feels tacked on, and as is usual with the Unreal Tournament series, it's still basically just Unreal Tournament matches, but the game puts tidbits of story in with things so it feels like an actual game.

This ended up taking like half the review, but, hey, it needs to be asked, why? Is this Unreal 3, or Unreal Tournament 4? It can't be 3, that was done already. There wasn't even an Unreal Tournament 2, if you're not counting the two yearly games, 2003 and 2004. Which would make this Unreal Tournament 2. But that's nonsensical. I just don't see where they got 3 from. On top of this, Epic Games DID have a hand in all three of the previous games... I don't get it.

reviewText:
I want to like this game, I really do, but I just can't.

Having bought this game 3 times now (PS3, PC collectors' ed. and now Steam) and playing well over 100 hours across, as an arena shooter this game has some things going for it, but as a UT sequel and in light of the plethora of good team-arena shooters out there falls painfully short.

First of all, one staple objective-driven gametype (assault) and another innovative football-like gametype introduced in UT2K4 (bombing run) have been axed entirely. Warfare (formerly onslaught) has undergone a number of questionable design choices (insta-capture orbs) which altar game flow dramatically. Many of the movement options which made UT2K4 a hit with the competitive scence as well as 'adrenaline' combos (admittedly a controversial addition in the first place) are no longer.

However perhaps the most glaring design failure was the direction Epic decided to steer this game. Hot on the heels of Gears of Wars' success and with plenty of unused art assets, Epic tossed out the Tournament canon in favor of an extremely lackluster filler campaign akin to those that ship with the yearly COD releases. Furthermore, many prominent and loved tourney combatants were either removed or attached to an unrecognizable body. Graphically these bodies have been disfigured and hyper-muscularized and the lush arenas of previous titles have been tossed out in favor of the muddy, bloom and postprocessing-heavy urban jungles so characteristic of its generation. It's also worth noting that unlike its namesake, this game came out on console first and shipped to PC with a (since partially fixed) console UI. This disrespect for canon and shoddy presentation make clear one thing: on release, Epic simply valued money over their fan base.

Sure, Epic didn't completely abandon the title, to their credit releasing several solid maps, patches and the Titan bonus pack, as well as sponsoring tournaments and the Make Something Unreal contest, but it was still only a band-aid over the aforementioned lacerating flaws of this title. Note that this support (long-since ended) came and went 3-years-ago, the community having dwindled to, at the time of this writing, one-to-three scantly populated servers per game mode (compared to 10-20 near-capacity in UT99/UT2K4).

Did Epic release a few interesting new features for this game? Sure, the hoverboard/grapple is invaluable over larger maps and Warfare's bonus nodes bring variety to the mode; several of the new maps are also well-designed. However, it's a big loss compared to what you are giving up from the previous titles and I'd recommend that if you're into the larger-scale or competitive aspects look into UT2K4, quake-like team-arena modes UT99. Viewed apart from the series, it's a mediocre team-arena shooter with a weak community, and even Tribes: Ascend will serve you better.

ANOTHER IMPORTANT NOTE: If you do own a retail PC copy of UT3, you can save yourself the expense and redeem the key for a free Steam copy.

Campaign is not as good as the typical tournaments were. The new lore about respawners and them being powered by flags (CTF) is just stupid.

reviewText:
(even though it says just a few minutes on record, I actually played much more, but it was retail non-Steam version)

If you like old school online FPS, gameplay will likely suit you. It's pretty great. Never play campaign, though. The game is online shooter, I don't really know why they included campaign in the first place. Every UT game included one, though.
Some people argue that UT2004 is better in terms of gameplay, but I believe it's a matter of taste. I have played and enjoyed both games.

There's large assortiment of maps (both official and community-made, everything for free, no stupid DLCs), characters, and other mods. Some people even find enjoyment in trying various maps and mods with bots offline. As for me, playing offline is largely useless, but YMMV. It's pretty easy to mod the game, though it's the case for other UT games as well.

Graphics is largely outdated, but so many years have passed since the release, and who cares, anyway? What I don't like is the style. It's dark, gloomy and overdetailed. I liked UT2004 more. Community-made HOLP map pack for this game has maps that better suit my taste.

The soundtrack is great, but so-called dynamic music wasted it, in my opinion. I play with in-game music turned off, but sometimes listen to OST separately.

What really ruined the game is lack of developer support. Although several patches were released that had addressed outright bugs (honestly, Valve games like TF2 faced much more disgraceful bugs during their lifetime), Epic Games never seemed to really care about this game. It's hard to tell what's exactly should've done about this, but for some reason TF2 is still alive and well, despite being released roughly at the same time and failing into the same niche of old school shooters.

There's a lot of small issues that aren't exactly game-breaking, but still prevent from enjoying the game fully. Like fragile replay support (try to play a demo recorded on server with mods on), buggy dedicated server on Linux (and no client whatsoever), frequent issues with GameSpy middleware, technical issues with with custom gametypes (to be precise, cooking map made for custom gametype causes trouble if gametype is ever updated), lack of proper custom crosshair support, inability to switch to spectator from player, and a lot of other problems that were certainly mentioned on Epic Games forums multitude of times.

As of now, game is almost dead. I do play it occasionally, you can find some players online, but still. If you like playing custom maps with bots, though, you still might enjoy it.

The single player campaign is a bit of a let down, the gameplay is really fun, but the story is hard to follow. A few characters seem cool but never get developed, the few cutscenes and mission briefing voiceovers do not effectively convey the story. It's a shame there weren't more teams/factions/clans introduced, and I was particularly bummed that the Skaarj didn't make an appearance. Character models sadly seemed more like Gears of War leftovers than of Unreal Tournament design. So while the sloppily thrown together single player campaign is a tad disappointing, the overall gameplay is still great fun and it looks great. More fun than UT2k3 and UT2k4!

Introduction: This has been one of mine favorite video game franchises ever since I played Unreal Tournament 2004!
And coming to this one I wouldn't say everything is great about this as compared to UT2K4 especially the movement and gravity though it can be fixed with mods but besides that there are many new games modes like Greed, Betrayal and the improved Onslaught mode from UT2K4 called Warfare which is my favorite as its relatively more balanced now.
I didn't like the Titan mutator much but then again it can be turned off.
The amount of community made mods, maps and other stuff is big though not as big as UT2K4.

Weapons: The shield gun has been replaced with the Impact Hammer from the original UT and all other weapons have been modified in some way or the other which is a mixed bag in my opinion. Translocator is also still there for non vehicular combat game modes.

Vehicles: With the inclusion of the new Necris faction in to the Unreal Tournament universe there are several new vehicles on top of those which already existed in UT2K4 so I can't describe all of them in detail here because I initially wanted to as each and every vehicle is fun to use! So if you get the game just jump in to Vehicle Capture The Flag or Warfare and try them out yourself! Besides this a new Translocator alternative called the Hoverboard has been added for vehicular combat game modes.

Campaign: Even though I have played all the Unreal Tournament games I'm not a that big fan of its storyline so I didn't expect much from this ones Campaign either as its boring with only a few cutscenes. Though if you have a friend then I would suggest playing Co Op on the Insane difficulty mode! You can add me as well if you want to play Co Op!

Multiplayer: Since the new Unreal Tournament has been in development which is currently in Beta as of now the Multiplayer community has been mostly dead so at this point of time it is a little hard even for a big fan of this series like me to blindly recommend this for Multiplayer which is one of the strongest point of this game. Mostly you will find bots on the servers though you can find some dedicated players occassionally.

Conclusion: Overall in short you can consider this game during a sale if you haven't played a fast paced First Person Shooter in a while which relies on a lot of things like skills, reflexes, strategy and team work depending on the game mode. There aren't any locked content except character visual customization so you have everything available from the start for an instant action!

I don't dislike UT3, but to be honest I did prefer the previous versions.\n\nI don't think the graphics are as good, it all looks very black and white and it just doesn't feel like UT should do to me.
